Savitz becomes third Hopkins student to win Rhodes prize
By MICHAEL MANES
For the third time in the history of the University, a senior
has been awarded the Rhodes'
scholarship to attend Oxford
University for at least two years.
Andrew Wade Savitz, President
of the Student Council for three
years, will receive his B.A. in Political Science this June and, in
October, leave the country for
the opportunity of a lifetime
The scholarship bears the
founder's name, Cecil John
Rhodes, who was a South American statesman and diamond and
gold mine owner. In addition to
being a great builder of the
british Empire, Rhodes was a
man who believed in self-guided
destiny. He believed the
Anglo-Saxon culture to be the
highest in the world, and desired,
through the growth of the empire, "to found a power great
enough to make wars impossible."
Rhodes established in his will
the special maintenance of
scholarships to Oxford because
he considered `...that the education of young colonists at one of
the universities in the United
Kingdom is of great advantage to
them for giving breadth to their
views, for their instruction in life
and manners for instilling into
their minds the advantage to the
colonies as well as the United
Kingdom of the retention of the
unity of the empire"
As disclosed in Rhodes- last
will, which was made in 1899,
the scholars would include all
